text: What would be the best package to use for multivariate time series forecasting?

elements.text: What would be the best package to use for multivariate time series forecasting?

text: Not sure about the best, but you could try <https://github.com/fipelle/TSAnalysis.jl> or one of the gaussian process libraries.

elements.text: Not sure about the best, but you could try
or one of the gaussian process libraries.

text: It's a little overwhelming, but here's a discourse thread from last year that lists almost all of the relevant libraries in this space: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/how-can-we-create-a-leaner-ecosystem-for-julia/32904>

attachments.title: How can we create a leaner ecosystem for Julia?
attachments.text: Comparisons of Julia w/ other languages often say one disadvantage of Julia is that it has fewer 3rd party packages. I tend to disagree. Julia doesn’t need more packages, it needs better packages (w/ more functionality). For example, two recent posts about time-series (here) & (here) highlight the amount of redundancy & lack of cooperation between Julia developers. Consider some packages listed in the posts & others I found on my own: TSAnalysis, ARFIMA,StateSpaceModels, ARMAProcesses, TimeS...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: How can we create a leaner ecosystem for Julia?

elements.text: Is there any particular methodology you are looking to use, or any particular constraints on your problem?

text: No constraints per se — I am just starting a project and am currently at the data exploration stage. Not even sure if we can forecast the thing so looking for both a good baseline as well as recommendations for more complex models
